caption: A KGB agent admitted that the Sex Pistols were financed by the USSR to destabilize Western democracy.

result.explanation: The entities "Sex Pistols" and "USSR" are correctly identified and contextually relevant to the caption. However, the inclusion of entities like "The Engine Room##s Southampton", "John L##ydon", "Public Image Ltd", and other locations seems out of place and unrelated to the main subject of the caption.  The presence of these entities lowers confidence.  Without them, the core assertion would hold.

candidates.title: Did a KGB Agent Confirm That the Sex Pistols Were Backed by the USSR to Destabilize the West?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A KGB agent admitted that the Sex Pistols were financed by the USSR to destabilize Western democracy.
Rating:
False
About this rating
On 9 May 2017, Facebook page "The Church of PUNK" shared an article reporting that a KGB agent admitted the band the Sex Pistols were an operation backed by the former Soviet Union to destabilize Western democracy:
The April 2015 article reported that at the time it was published, a former KGB agent had just disclosed the punk rock plot:
Alexandrei Varennikovic Voloshin, a retired KGB agent, has admitted this week on National Russian Television (NTV) that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) was behind the creation of the 1970s punk scene and financed major punk bands such as the Sex Pistols, the Clash and the Ramones.
The USSR government at the time spent “hundreds of millions of rubles” on this covert operation destined to “create utter chaos” and “pervert the Western youth to nihilist, anti-establishment and anti-american ideologies” he explained in an hour long interview broadcast on national television.
There is no truth to this story; World News Daily Report states on its own disclaimer page that all of the content on the site is fictional:
WNDR assumes however all responsibility for the satirical nature of its articles and for the fictional nature of their content. All characters appearing in the articles in this website – even those based on real people – are entirely fictional and any resemblance between them and any persons, living, dead, or undead is purely a miracle.
candidates.description: A Facebook page for punk fans recirculated an old (and fake) story that the Sex Pistols were a KGB plot to foment dissent in the West.

result.explanation: This assessment is based on external evidence from Snopes.  The claim that a KGB agent admitted the Sex Pistols were financed by the USSR to destabilize Western democracy is FALSE.  Snopes traces the claim to a satirical article from World News Daily Report, which explicitly states that its content is fictional.  The external evidence directly contradicts the news caption, showing it to be inaccurate and misused.
supporting_evidence: Source 1: Snopes fact-check debunks the claim, identifying it as originating from a satirical website that labels its content as fictional.
Source 1:  The Snopes article quotes the disclaimer from World News Daily Report stating all content is fictional.

final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external checks strongly indicate that the original news caption is false and out of context.  The external check definitively debunks the claim using a Snopes fact-check, tracing the origin to a satirical website.  The internal check highlights inconsistencies in the extracted entities, further reducing confidence in the caption's accuracy. There is no valid support for the claim that a KGB agent admitted USSR's financing of the Sex Pistols to destabilize Western democracy. The entities unrelated to the central claim further diminish the credibility of the original caption.  The overall confidence score is very high (10) due to the strong agreement and conclusive nature of both internal and external evidence against the caption's validity. The caption is factually incorrect and entirely out of context.  There is no credible evidence supporting the stated claim about the Sex Pistols' funding and intended purpose. The external evidence decisively shows that the claim is fabricated and originates from a source that explicitly labels its content as fictional. The internal check also revealed issues with entity extraction, indicating that additional unrelated entities were included, suggesting a lack of coherence and context within the original text from which the caption was derived, further reinforcing its out-of-context and inaccurate nature. Overall, the original caption is fundamentally untrue and its placement alongside the entities is not contextually appropriate. This conclusion is based on the conclusive evidence presented by the external fact-check and the internal analysis of the extracted entities, both of which point to the caption being entirely false and devoid of any factual basis. Therefore, the caption is determined to be completely out of context and inaccurate, thus having an OOC value of 'True' and a high confidence score of 10. The weight is largely placed on the external verification, which is based on a reputable fact-checking source that provides clear evidence and links that disprove the claim. The internal analysis complements this by pointing out further inconsistencies in the surrounding text, therefore reinforcing the overall judgment and conclusion. The absence of supporting evidence for the claim and the presence of evidence directly contradicting it, strengthens the accuracy of the final assessment. As a result, there's a lack of context and veracity associated with the news caption, making it entirely out of context and unreliable. Therefore, the claim is conclusively false and out of context. The external verification from Snopes provides strong, reliable evidence that completely refutes the claim presented in the original caption. This evidence comes from a trusted source with a reputation for providing accurate fact-checks.   Combining the external verification's complete refutation of the claim and the internal analysis's indication of contextual issues, the overall judgment is clear and definitive.
